dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Google acquired DeepMind in 2014, four years after Suleyman cofounded the London-based lab with CEO Demis Hassabis, and the reported price tag400 million pounds or $650 million U.S. at the timesignified its big ambitions in artificial intelligence and DeepMinds technical expertise.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then look what happened—DeepMind's pretax profits grew to 100 million dollars by 2020, with a billion in sales. That's not exactly "losing money."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then look what happened-DeepMind's pretax profits grew to one hundred million dollars by twenty twenty, with a billion in sales. That's not exactly losing money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Google parent company Alphabet doesnt break out the balance sheets of its individual businesses in its earnings reports, but recent documents filed with the U.K.'s Companies House registry show that in 2018 DeepMinds pretax losses grew to $570 million with revenues of $125 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Although, uh, The Information did report back in April 2020 that Suleyman's team was essentially responsible for finding ways for DeepMind to lose money. So maybe there was some internal tension?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And then there's his stance on ethics—he wrote in Wired that we should abandon the "hard, impractical work of ethical AI."

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We need to do the hard, practical and messy work of finding out what ethical AI really means, he wrote in a Wired op-ed in 2018, predicting that the study of the safety and societal impact of AI was going to be one of the most pressing areas of enquiry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is pretty controversial, especially since he and Zuckerberg disbanded DeepMind's internal ethics board after the acquisition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is pretty controversial, especially since he and Zuckerberg disbanded DeepMind's internal ethics board after the acquisition.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As part of Google's acquisition of DeepMind, he and Hassabis even required that the company set up an internal ethics board to oversee AI work across all divisions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And yet now Google has this external AI ethics council that's apparently been highly successful. It's like a complete turnaround from his earlier philosophy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet now Google has this external A I ethics council that's apparently been highly successful. It's like a complete turnaround from his earlier philosophy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this year, Google tried to create an external artificial intelligence ethics council, but quickly dissolved the project in the wake of internal and external protest over its members.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think his return signals that Google is prioritizing commercialization over ethical safeguards again?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think his return signals that Google is prioritizing commercialization over ethical safeguards again?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's possible—especially with projects like that InstaFace app, where they had access to 16 million user records.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's possible-especially with projects like that InstaFace app, where they had access to sixteen million user records.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The collaboration gave DeepMind access to 1.6 million patient records for a kidney monitoring app called Streams, and its data-sharing practices were ultimately deemed illegal in 2017, prompting an apology from Suleyman and the company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And that partnership with the U.S. Department of Defense back in 2015… it just shows how deeply they're embedded in real-world applications, ethics aside.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, it's fascinating to see someone with such a dismissive view of A I ethics stepping back into a major leadership role at Google.

artist_script:
DeepMind's co-founder Mustafa Suleyman is back at Google, and it's a move that could reshape the company's AI ambitions.
HostA: Yeah, Mustafa Suleyman returning to Google after that six-month sabbatical is huge, especially given their past data privacy fallout.
HostB: Right? And he’s not just coming back to any role—Bloomberg reported he’s leading new projects meant to revolutionize their product lineup.
HostA: Which is wild, considering his history with DeepMind. I mean, Facebook acquired it back in 2010 for 100 million dollars, right?
HostB: Exactly, and at the time, that price tag was seen as a sign of Facebook’s minimal ambition in AI—almost like they underestimated what DeepMind could do.
HostA: But then look what happened—DeepMind’s pretax profits grew to 100 million dollars by 2020, with a billion in sales. That’s not exactly "losing money."
HostB: Although, uh, The Information did report back in April 2020 that Suleyman’s team was essentially responsible for finding ways for DeepMind to lose money. So maybe there was some internal tension?
HostA: For sure. And then there’s his stance on ethics—he wrote in Wired that we should abandon the "hard, impractical work of ethical AI."
HostB: Which is pretty controversial, especially since he and Zuckerberg disbanded DeepMind’s internal ethics board after the acquisition.
HostA: And yet now Google has this external AI ethics council that’s apparently been highly successful. It’s like a complete turnaround from his earlier philosophy.
HostB: Do you think his return signals that Google is prioritizing commercialization over ethical safeguards again?
HostA: It’s possible—especially with projects like that InstaFace app, where they had access to 16 million user records.
HostB: And that partnership with the U.S. Department of Defense back in 2015… it just shows how deeply they’re embedded in real-world applications, ethics aside.
HostA: Still, it’s fascinating to see someone with such a dismissive view of AI ethics stepping back into a major leadership role at Google.
HostB: Absolutely. This is gonna be one to watch.
